paragraph.paragraph: EiffelEnvision project's file system is build from enumerating the contents of a url*cluster location. The enumeration process finds and adds all located Eiffel source file (*.e) and adds them to a project based on their discovered location. No other files are added to the project unless they have been explicitly added at some point in the project's life. For more information, see url*Cluster Nodes

To add existing file(s), select a folder node in your EiffelEnvision project. Now select Project, Add Existing File... (SHIFT+ALT+A). Alternatively select the Add, Add Existing File... from the folder node context menu. Once selected a file browser dialog will be displayed. Located and select the file you would like to add to the project and clikc Ok, Cancel will close the file dialog and no file will be added to the project.
If the url*Project Node is selected when adding an existing file, the file will be added under the url*Project Items section of your project, because they share the same url*Path. Adding non-Eiffel source file (*.e) existing files may only be done using the url*Project Items Node and it's subfolders and url*clusters, as well the url*Other Project Items Node and its subfolders. Any existing Eiffel source file may be added to any one of the folders in an EiffelEnvision project. For more information on this restriction, see url*Project Items Node.

Because EiffelEnvision url*Projects directly reflect an underlying file system, adding existing files to folders whose url*Path is not the same as the location of the file being added to the project, the added file will be copied to the folder url*Path and then added. This is exactly how other Visual Studio .NET langauges that vxconFolder-BasedReference-BasedProjects 0 managed project using files act.

For the url*Other Files Node and it's subfolders, adding existing files will not be copied. This is because url*Other Files vxconFolder-BasedReference-BasedProjects 0 link to files and does not have a direct representation of them, base on the underlying file system.
